title: Buying Property in Spain: Step-by-Step Process 2026
excerpt: Complete guide to the Spanish property buying process. From initial search to key handover - every step explained for international buyers.
author: New Build Homes Costa Blanca

content.quickAnswer: The Spanish property buying process takes 6-12 weeks for resales, 12-24 months for new builds. Key steps: reservation deposit (€3-6k), private purchase contract (10% deposit), completion at notary (full payment). Always use an independent lawyer and get NIE number early.
content.intro: Buying property in Spain follows a structured process that, once understood, is straightforward and secure. This guide walks you through every step, from initial search to receiving your keys, with practical advice based on thousands of successful purchases.

sections.title: Step 1: Define Your Requirements
sections.content:
Before viewing properties, clarify your priorities:

**Location questions:**
- Beach proximity or peaceful inland?
- North Costa Blanca (dramatic, upmarket) or South (sunny, social)?
- Near airport? Alicante serves both regions
- Golf course access important?

**Property questions:**
- Villa, townhouse, or apartment?
- New build or resale?
- Number of bedrooms/bathrooms?
- Pool essential or nice-to-have?
- Budget including 13% buying costs?

**Practical questions:**
- Will you rent it out?
- How often will you visit?
- Need lock-up-and-leave security?
- Future resale potential important?

Write these down. They help agents find suitable properties and prevent time-wasting viewings.

sections.title: Step 2: Get Your Finances Ready
sections.content:
**If paying cash:**
- Ensure funds are accessible
- Plan for international transfers (use specialist like CurrencyFair or Wise)
- Open Spanish bank account (can do in person or remotely)

**If needing mortgage:**
- Get agreement in principle BEFORE making offers
- Spanish banks lend 60-70% to non-residents
- Process takes 4-6 weeks for approval
- Compare rates through mortgage broker

**Currency considerations:**
- Fix exchange rate to protect budget
- Forward contracts lock in rate for future payment
- Currency fluctuations can add/cost thousands

**Proof of funds:**
- Sellers may request bank statements
- Mortgage agreement in principle
- Shows you're a serious buyer

sections.title: Step 3: Property Viewing Trip
sections.content:
**Organize efficiently:**
- Book 3-4 days minimum
- View 8-12 properties maximum per day
- Mix of areas to compare
- Second viewing of favorites before leaving

**What to look for:**
- Orientation (south-facing best for winter sun)
- Storage and parking
- Community facilities condition
- Noise levels at different times
- Mobile phone signal
- Walk the neighborhood

**Questions to ask:**
- Community fees amount and what's included
- Any special assessments planned?
- How old is the roof/AC/pool equipment?
- Why is owner selling?
- How long on market?

**New builds specifically:**
- Visit completed phases if available
- Check developer track record
- Understand specification included vs upgrades
- Timeline and payment schedule

sections.title: Step 4: Make an Offer
sections.content:
**Offer process:**
- Submit in writing through agent
- Include: price, conditions, timeline
- Typically 5-10% below asking is acceptable
- New builds usually fixed price

**Negotiation points:**
- Price (primary)
- Furniture/contents included
- Completion date flexibility
- Repairs or improvements
- Fixtures and fittings

**Once offer accepted:**
- Verbal agreement only - not binding
- Move quickly to reservation
- Appoint lawyer immediately if not already done

sections.title: Step 5: Reservation & Due Diligence
sections.content:
**Reservation deposit:**
- €3,000-10,000 typical
- Removes property from market
- Usually non-refundable
- Applied to purchase price

**Your lawyer should check:**
- Property registered correctly
- Seller is legal owner
- No debts attached (mortgages, embargos)
- No illegal construction
- Community fees paid up to date
- Urban planning status (no planned roads through garden!)
- Energy certificate valid

**Get your NIE:**
- Start process immediately
- Required for contracts and completion
- Lawyer can handle this

**For new builds:**
- Check building license valid
- Developer has bank guarantee
- Specifications detailed in contract
- Payment schedule and penalties

sections.title: Step 6: Private Purchase Contract
sections.content:
**The key document:**
- Legally binding on both parties
- Typically 10% deposit paid (less reservation)
- Sets completion date
- Details all terms and conditions

**Contract should include:**
- Full property description
- Exact price and payment terms
- Completion date
- What's included (furniture, etc.)
- Penalty clauses for non-completion
- Conditions (subject to mortgage, surveys, etc.)

**If you withdraw:**
- Lose your 10% deposit
- Seller keeps it as compensation

**If seller withdraws:**
- They pay you double your deposit (20%)
- Strong protection for buyers

sections.title: Step 7: Arrange Completion
sections.content:
**Before completion:**
- Final funds transferred to Spanish account
- Lawyer prepares deed (escritura)
- Notary appointment booked
- Final property inspection
- Meter readings taken

**At the notary:**
- Seller, buyer (or representatives) attend
- Deed read aloud in Spanish
- Translator provided if needed
- Sign multiple copies
- Pay remaining balance
- Receive keys

**Immediately after:**
- Lawyer registers deed at Land Registry
- Pays taxes on your behalf
- Transfers utilities to your name
- You're officially the owner!

sections.title: New Build Timeline
sections.content:
**Off-plan purchase typical timeline:**

**Month 1:**
- Reservation deposit (€3-10k)
- Private contract (20-30% of price)

**Construction period (12-24 months):**
- Stage payments as building progresses
- Typically 3-4 additional payments
- Each tied to construction milestones

**Pre-completion:**
- Snagging list inspection
- Final customization choices
- Arrange mortgage drawdown if applicable

**Completion:**
- Final payment (usually 30-40%)
- First Occupation License issued
- Sign at notary, receive keys

**Bank guarantees:**
- All deposits held in protected account
- If developer fails, money returned
- Required by Spanish law for off-plan

content.conclusion:
The Spanish buying process is well-regulated and protects both parties. Success comes from preparation: get finances ready, appoint a good lawyer early, and don't rush major decisions. Most international buyers complete without issues and wonder why they waited so long to buy their Spanish dream home.
